MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Social Employment Scheme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the position regarding the employment of social employment scheme workers in schools for the academic year starting September 1993.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The social employment scheme is the principal manpower intervention aimed at providing opportunities for persons who are long term unemployed. Schools have sponsored projects under the scheme relating to the provision of services such as caretaking, secretarial and other ancilliary services. All projects under the scheme must be approved by a national monitoring committee.

I am aware that the ICTU, which is represented on the monitoring committee, has indicated that it will oppose the approval of any further school based projects pending a satisfactory resolution of difficulties regarding the filling of permanent caretaker and secretary posts in schools.

I understand that the relevant union is pursuing the matter with the Minister for Education and I hope that the difficulties can be resolved to the satisfaction of all concerned so as to ensure the continued availability of opportunities in schools under the SES for persons who are long term unemployed.
The filling of individual places on the SES is of course a day to day matter for FÁS and is subject to the availability of funds.

Qst.Quest: if he has examined the feasibility of allowing the long term unemployed to undertake employment with statutory bodies such as health boards, local authorities and other such bodies on foot of their unemployment assistance payments plus a sum of approximately £50 per week; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that the recruitment procedures of health boards, local authorities and other such bodies is a matter for the respective Ministers in consultation with the Minister for Finance.

MainHeading.P: In so far as my area of responsibility is concerned, opportunities for the long term employed are made available by FÁS through the social employment scheme which is the principal manpower intervention aimed at persons who are long term unemployed. Projects under the scheme are sponsored by public sector bodies as well as by voluntary groups involving work which would not otherwise be undertaken. Participants are paid allowances which are higher than the rates to which they were entitled while on the Live Register. The current basic rate is £75 per week compared with £57.20 per week unemployment assistance. This means that a participant with one adult and three child dependants receives £145 per week compared with £129 while on the Live Register. I am pleased to say that the rates of payment will increase from July, when social welfare payments are set to increase.
I am satisfied that the existing arrangements for involving public sector bodies in the social employment scheme are satisfactory and I have no plans to alter them.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Plastic Oil Storage Tanks Standards.

Qst.Quest: the standards that are currently in existence in this country for the manufacture and installation of plastic oil storage tanks; and if he has satisfied himself with the performance of such tanks under fire conditions, particularly when compared with steel tanks.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: There is no Irish or European standard for plastic oil storage tanks. However, CEN, the European Committee for Standardisation (of which Ireland, through the National Standards Authority of Ireland, is a member) is drawing up a standard for these products. When this standard is published, the member states will be obliged to adopt it as a national standard.
I am not aware of any problems in relation to the performance of plastic oil storage tanks.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - County Galway Foreshore Licence Application.

Qst.Quest: if a foreshore licence under the Foreshore Act, 1933, has been granted to a company (details supplied) over an area of the foreshore in Barnaderg Bay, Ballinakill Harbour, County Galway; and, if so, the date the licence was issued to this company.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: An application for a foreshore lease to develop a car park facility at the location in question was received in January 1992.

The application was at that time fully assessed by the engineering branch of the Department of the Marine and there was no objection to the proposal on technical grounds. The Department also sought the advice of Bord Fáilte which, in March 1992, indicated that they had no objection on amenity grounds.

Following these assessments the company involved, on the direction of the Department of the Marine under the Foreshore Act, 1993, published notice of the proposal in two local newspapers (Connacht Tribune on 3 April 1992 and Connacht Sentinel on 14 April 1992). No objection was received in response to these advertisements or otherwise until recent weeks. In the meantime Galway County Council gave notice of its decision to grant planning permission on 30 June 1992 and confirmed its decision on 4 August 1992.
A formal offer of a lease was made to the company on 8 March 1993 and following negotiations on the terms of the lease the company formally accepted it on 1 June 1993.

MainHeading.P: It came to notice early in May that work had commenced on the site in advance of the finalisation of the lease. The applicant was advised that no authority to commence work on the site had been granted and that all works should cease pending finalisation of the lease. Galway County Council issued a warning notice under the Planning Acts on 25 May requiring that the development be discontinued forthwith.

While it remains the intention to grant a lease as originally offered and accepted, the formalities will not be finalised until I am satisfied that the works will be in accordance with plans and drawings approved by me and that the Local Authority requirements will be satisfied.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Youth Arts Activities Funding.

Qst.hpid: Ms F. Fitzgerald Ms F. Fitzgerald
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: if he intends to fund youth clubs and youth arts activities in order to ensure that arts and culture are fully integrated into youth work organisations; and the policy initiatives, if any, he intends to take in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: Responsibility for funding initiatives such as those raised by the Deputy rests with An Chomhairle Ealaíon. I recently had the pleasure of launching “Making Youth Arts Work”, the final report of the National Youth Arts Committee. This committee was established in 1990 to undertake policy development in the area of youth arts (the arts experiences of young people ouside of schools) and was a joint initiative by an Chomhairle Ealaíon and the National Youth Council of Ireland.

Broadly speaking, the report identifies the need for a policy led and co-ordinated approach to the development of youth arts by organisations with responsibility in this area, namely the Youth Affairs section of the Department of Education, An Chomhairle Ealaíon, national and local agencies involved in youth services work, youth and arts organisations.

I understand that the recommendations of the report have been adopted by An Chomhairle Ealaíon and will be further considered in the context of a formal liaison committee currently being established between An Chomhairle and the Department of Education.

I believe that initiatives such as this will help ensure that youth organisations are in a position to offer young people an opportunity to develop their interest in the whole area of arts and culture. This will reap long term benefits in terms of enhanced participation in the arts to the benefit of society in general.

Qst.hpid: Ms. F. Fitzgerald Ms. F. Fitzgerald
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht
Qst.Quest: his views on the establishment of a North/South TV Station in conjunction with the relevant authorities in Northern Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins) Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins)
Speaker.P: I have no plans at present for the establishment of such a service. I would prefer to see in the short term greater equality of editorial choice for television viewers in the whole island of Ireland with existing services.

The policy of successive Irish Governments has been to encourage plurality of television choice and Northern Ireland television services are available to ever increasing numbers of viewers here through natural overspill, cable and MMDS retransmission systems. Unfortunately, reception of RTE television services in Northern Ireland is less than satifactory, being available to about 40 per cent of the population. Any improvement in this situation involves the successful negotiation of bi-lateral and multi-lateral agreements on the use of broadcasting frequency spectrum within the constraints of International Agreements to which Ireland and the UK are parties. Such negotiations are primarily a matter for my colleague, the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications, but I would hope that in due course it will be possible to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement that will result in the greater availability of RTE television services in Northern Ireland. In this regard I would hope also that it may be possible for Telefís na Gaeilge to be an all Ireland television service.

Qst.Quest: the reason doctors being offered contracts are only being offered six month contracts at present; if he considers this to be one of the reasons so many of our junior doctors are emigrating; and his views on whether there is a major expense to the health board advertising these posts every six months.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, Non-Consultant Hospital Doctors (NCHDs) are doctors in training. The programmes laid down by the training bodies require NCHDs to gain experience in various specialities. This is typically broken into blocks of six months. Many NCHDs are participants in organised rotation schemes lasting 2-3 years made up of a varying number of six month blocks.
There has been no change in this system in recent times.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Hospital Out-Patient Charge.

Qst.Quest: the reason persons suffering from diabetes are now required to pay a hospital charge when they attend a hospital, whereas previously they did not have to pay; and when this change was made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: I presume that the Deputy is referring to the statutory out-patient charge. With effect from 1 March, 1993 the previous charge of £10 for the first visit in relation to the treatment of a particular condition was replaced by a charge of £6 for each visit, subject to a maximum liability of £42 per individual in any period of twelve consecutive months.

MainHeading.P: Persons suffering from diabetes other than medical card holders were not exempt from the charge under the previous system and their position has not changed in that respect.

I have already announced that I am having a full review of public hospital charges carried out. I have received correspondence from the Irish Diabetic Association relating to the out-patient charge and I have asked the Review Group to look specifically at the points raised in the correspondence. Whatever changes are made as a result of this review will be implemented next year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - County Roscommon School Facilities.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the serious lack of basic facilities at Killmurry National School, Castlerea, County Roscommon; and when the necessary grants will be made available to commence on an improvements programme at the school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware that the managerial authorities of Killmurry National School, Castlerea, Co. Roscommon have applied for grant-aid towards the cost of major improvement works to the school building and site.
The application is under examination in my Department at present and it is hoped to have a decision in the matter shortly.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a complaint from a person (details supplied) in County Wicklow who, despite six years experience has not been re-appointed as an assistant examiner for the junior certificate art examination and who has not even been placed on the reserve panel; if she has had the complaint investigated; if so, the outcome of the investigation and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: My Department selects from the applicants each year the panel of assistant examiners which it considers most suitable in each particular subject.
Selection as an examiner in any one year does not confer on any applicant the right to be selected in subsequent years.
You will appreciate that it would not be appropriate for me to go into the reasons why one applicant rather than another was selected.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - County Dublin Remedial Teacher Appointment.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a request from Archbishop McQuaid Senior School, Loughlinstown, County Dublin, for the appointment of a remedial teacher; and if she intends to honour the commitment which she gave to the parents' committee of the school that such an appointment would be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am pleased to inform the Deputy that the school in question has been selected for receipt of a remedial service with effect from September, 1993. The post is being allocated to the school on shared basis with Kilmacanogue National School, Co. Wicklow.
My Department will be in touch with the schools shortly to make the necessary arrangements.
